chunks: NORMALIZED DERIVATIONS FOR MILNOR’S PRIMITIVE OPERATIONS ON THE DICKSON ALGEBRA AND APPLICATIONS D-Ă.NG VÕ PHÚC∗ Abstract.Our work investigates the action of primitive Milnor operationsSt∆ion the Dick- son algebraD noverF p, building upon a foundational formula by Nguyen Sum [5]. Our central contribution is the introduction of a normalized operator,δ i, by factoring out the ubiquitous invariantQ n,0. This normalization transformsSt∆iinto a true derivation on the localized Dickson algebra, thereby establishing an elegant differential framework. This framework yields two new significant results: first, a closed-form formula for all higher iterates of the operator, revealing a strong factorial-based vanishing criterion for iterates of order≥p. Second, the discovery of a normalized coordinate system where the action has constant coefficients. This latter insight reduces the problem of computing the associated Margolis homology to a stan- dard Koszul complex computation, in direct analogy with a recent result by Ngo Anh Tuan [6]. As further consequences, we also construct a large family of kernel elements and describe the global structure of the action. Keywords:Dickson invariants, Steenrod algebra, Milnor operations, Modular invariant theory, Derivation, Margolis homology, Koszul homology. MSC (2020):55S10, 13A50, 55N99. 1.Introduction Letpbe a prime andP n=F p[x1,...,x n]be the polynomial algebra with its naturalGL n(Fp)- action. The Dickson invariantsQ n,0,Qn,1,...,Q n,n−1generate a polynomial subalgebraD n, known as the Dickson algebra [1], that plays a central role in invariant theory and algebraic topology. Its importance is particularly pronounced in the study of the cohomology of ele- mentary abelianp-groups, whereD nappears as the ring of invariants under the action of the Steenrod algebra,A p. A fundamental problem, therefore, is to determine the structure ofD n as a module overA p. Milnor’s primitive operations [4], denoted here bySt∆i, are key components of the Steenrod algebra and act onP nas graded derivations. In a foundational paper [5], N. Sum provided an explicit closed formula for the action ofSt∆ion each Dickson generatorQ n,s. Sum’s identity expresses this action in the form St∆i(Qn,s) = (−1)nQn,0/parenleftbigg Pp n,i,s+Rp n,iQn,s/parenrightbigg , where the coefficientsP n,i,sandR n,iare themselves explicit polynomials in the Dickson invari- ants. While useful, this formula’s recurring factor ofQ n,0makes calculations of higher iterates cumbersome and obscures the underlying algebraic mechanics. The main goal of this paper is to show that, through an appropriate algebraic normalization, the complex action ofSt∆ican be reduced to that of a classical derivation. Our new contributions are twofold as follows: •A closed-form formula for iterates.We derive an explicit expression for them-th iterate(St∆i)mon any Dickson generator. This formula reveals a surprising connection to the factorialm!and provides a strong and simple vanishing criterion: the action is always zero form≥p. •A constant-coefficient structure and its application.We show that in a system of normalized coordinatesR s:=Q n,s/Qn,0, the operatorSt∆iacts withconstant coefficients. The primary contributions of this framework are twofold. First, it provides a closed-form expression for the higher iterates ofSt∆i, yield- ing a new and useful vanishing criterion (Theorem 2.4). This result transforms a previously cumbersome and combinatorially complex calculation into a direct substitution. Second, and more conceptually significant, this perspective uncovers a hidden constant-coefficient structure of the action when viewed in a normalized coordinate system (Theorem 2.12). This shows that it connects a specialized problem in algebraic topology to the standard theory of Koszul complexes, thereby simplifying the computation of the associated Margolis homology (Theorem 4.8).
